content:
8, 2016
												In 2008 DICE released a beautiful game: Mirror’s Edge!It’s a first-person action adventure game but movement and graphics are a unique, Mirror’s Edge was an innovation and is still a fantastic game. It’s one of the games I’ve played multiple times and one of that I played without a break. This game should be in every library on steam.StoryMirror’s Edge takes place in a unnamed, modern city where life is comfortable and crime almost non-existent. But the government is a totalitarianism regime which spies all communications and controls the media. People have to give up their personal freedom in this world. That’s the background story. I won’t tell more about the story because that would spoiler youGameplayAs I said above, the gameplay is unique and a real innovation, because you have a freedom of movement in the world you’ll have never seen in any game before. Faith is a runner, she has the ability to fight in melee [you can disarm enemies and use their weapons against them] and she’s a master in parkour running so you can use the complete environment to move forward. If you chain your movements you can build up a lot of speed. For example: You run a little bit, do a wall run, than you roll up on the floor and you continue to run with full speed. If you make any mistakes, you lose your speed. Faith is also able to knock out enemies with her body. For example she can use a wall run to build up speed and then jump to an enemy and kick him down or you disarm an enemy, knock him down and use the weapon against the others. But combat isn’t the focus, you can bypass the most situations, it’s better to run. The gameplay in Mirror’s Edge is so much fun unfortunately only the sequel Mirror’s Edge Catalyst has the same.A nice feature is that the camera is linked with the movement and that you see the body including arms and legs from Faith. Thanks to this you have a realistic feeling while playing this game.Graphic/SoundSurely you have already seen it, the graphics are very bright and have only a few colors, most of the time you see white. This is a special feature in Mirror’s Edge. It has its own art style which is very clean, almost clinically clean and minimalistic, it’s just beautiful. But it not only looks fantastic, it’s useful to retain the overview in the world. Also it matches to the city and the society, it accompanies the setting perfectly.The voice act is very nice like the complete soundscape. If you like ambient music, you’ll like the soundtrack here too. Solar Fields did a great job, the soundtrack is fantastic and Lisa Miskovsky created a masterpiece with Still Alive [not confuse with the Portal soundtrack].AtmosphereWith the unique graphic, the fascinating gameplay and the fantastic world Mirror’s Edge has its own very nice atmosphere. You are a lonely runner and most of the times you don’t see any allies, just hearing the voices and see enemies. You are against the world, a rebel refuses to be suppressed by the system that enslaves the people.Mirror’s Edge is one of the most unique games out there and a real masterpiece including many innovations. With a nice story, an impressive art style, a great soundtrack and an innovative and interesting gameplay you have more than one reason to buy this. I also recommend you Mirror’s Edge Catalyst, the sequel. It’s different because it has an open-world but it’s a nice game too. Unfortunately that you have to use Origin to play this.

content:
, 2014
												I really can't say I know of any games quite like this one. It may be short, but it leaves one heck of an impact, and will easily draw you in for more. Having previously played it on the Xbox 360, I can attest that while you can finish the whole story in one sitting with relative ease, you'll likely be playing the bits you liked over and over again.The story is where the game really shines. You quickly learn that the primarily trigger-based controls are, while unique, pretty intuitive after a while. Everything in the game feels natural pretty quickly. Finding a path, stringing together acrobatic moves, and generally making your way around. Only the combat really feels stilted, with a same few punch animations. You're mostly encouraged simply to disarm opponents by tapping the Y button when their weapon is highlighted, which gives you their gun and instantly knocks them out. This can get tedious, but pacifist runs are possible.The cutscenes have an animated comic sort of look to them. This is decent enough for getting the point across. The plot exists, primarily to get you between things to run around. It does a well enough job, and has quite a few surprises for only ten levels. The actual story levels themselves are like a combined puzzle platformer, as you mull over how to get where you're going and pull off some intensely satisfying parkour once you get the hang of it. The color scheme and lighting keeps the areas distinct from each other and easy on the eyes. It's a very particular, stylized look that benefits the game well.As for replay value, as the main story is short and sweet (it does not overstay its welcome by any stretch, but you may be expecting a bit more at the end), the game banks on you enjoying time trials. Really, really enjoying time trials. Because that's all there is. No other challenges in any way, shape, or form, just be the fastest. To be fair, it's quite clear the game is designed for this exact purpose when you start shaving valuable seconds off and learning how to keep momentum going throughout your run, but if you don't like them, already got the three runner bags hidden in each level, and, for whatever reason, don't feel a little thrill at pulling an awesome time off, you've pretty much finished the game as soon as the credits roll.The music is excellently fitting. The game overall can put a fantastic feeling of adrenaline into you, and a feeling of success when you figure out a new way through a level. There's no faster way to give someone a fear of heights than having them fall to their death in this game. The loading times are almost gone in the PC version (only three "Loading Level" screens still appeared for me), but the lengthy elevator rides and various delays meant to mask them are still perfectly intact, leading to some rather pointless waiting in the middle of a good run. Finally, the time trial scores are not registered through Steam. They are tracked through an EA Online account, which basically means you will not be finding your friend's times and racing your ghosts without a lot of undue effort.In the end, though, this is quite the amazing game, and I must still recommend it, if only because it leaves an amazing impression and stands alone as an experience. There's just nothing quite like it.

												This game brings back the good old parcour memories from the early 2009. I've played it around 2010 and lost the cd so after it was on sale on steam i bought it.There is nothing special to say about this game, it's a parcour game where you got control over a runner who is called Faith, im not going to spoiler more :)I finished the game in around 5 hours, good players are way faster.Good:-Different difficulty levels (they aren't that different imho)-The Enemy-KI is acceptable (cops are easy, pursuit cops are hard)-A lot of weapons (pistol, machine gun, shotgun, etc.)-Easy Control (easy to learn)-Good Graphic and Sound (it can contest many 2017 games)-The game is running fast, stable and the checkpoints are good setted-The Runners-Vision (doors, pipes, etc. are red, so you know where to go next) is a good help for new players-One fail (failed a jump in example) leads to death most of the time, first annoying, but very realistic-If the cops are shooting at you, you will run faster automatically, trust me :) -Most of the time you can avoid fights with cops and you are able to just run away or fight them, disarm them etc.-Extra stuff like artworks, music, video sequences and eastereggsNot so good:-New players will not be that fast, but if you are experienced you will beatthe game in around 3-5 hours, the 8 chapters aren't that big, could be more :)-It's always like go to this building, escape from the cops, a little bit boring-Roofs are most of the time looking the sameBugfix:If the game starts lagging really hard if the cops are shooting on you or glass shatters, you just have to disable "Nvidia PhysX" in the options ingame, you have to restart the game after and now it dosen't lag or freezes anymore (some graphic cards got problems with physx).What i can say:If the game is on sale (no idea why old games are always so expensive) and you want to give it a try, i can highly recommend it.

Product received for free
												Played this in 2016, it does look good! Count around 6 hours of playing if you're like me and don't care about all hidden secrets but prefer running & playing the story. 6 hours isn't much, but eh, I got the game for free, and I enjoyed those 6 hours, so :) The gameplay is very interesting, I played the entire thing with a xbox controller, and it's pleasant. The gunfights didn't exacly felt right (maybe it's the controller, go figure), but I still enjoyed to "shotgun those ninja's faces" (play it to understand!). I got about 3 or 4 good adrenaline rushes, but also felt like the game felt me 3 or 4 times (like: I swear I pushed the right button and I fell - and died - anyway. not kewl!). It's technical, but in general it goes quite smoothly, and the overall feeling is really good : run, run, (jump), run.The story itself isn't really interesting, the plot has some severe holes in it... but it does make sense to run like a crazy-person and jump from roof to roof if you can look past these inconsistencies, and I believe that's the main point of this game. I could somewhat compare it to Dying Light freerun on top of which you'd add new moves.Anyway, despite it being an "old" game in 2016, despite the story that could have been better and the lifespan double, I still recommend it to about anyone.

												Dropped in the middle of an Orwellian dystopia, the fragmented story told in animated cutscenes, loosely pulls together a string of well-designed parkour sequences which comprise of running from (and optionally gunning down) militarized police.While the basic parkour is fluid, I suffered motion sickness when knocked to the ground or falling from buildings, due to the wobble and sway of the first-person viewpoint and even with the onscreen reticle/dot. Yet another game where an option to switch between third and first viewpoints would improve the experience.Melee encounters are so few and far between that when forced into combat the lack of practice can breed frustration. While it's possible to avoid firing a shot for the entire game, I found it less frustrating (less checkpoint restarts) to use guns. There are also collectable packages, which didn't add any real challenge or in-game reward.While not a bad parkour title, it's still worthy of a recommendation, however I would play Assassin's Creed, Shadow of Mordor or Styx over this.- Skinny from the Fat B*stard (curator link)

												Mirror's Edge is a First Person Parcour Shooter... thingy.. I guess?You're playing the role of Faith, a girl having lost her parents and having only her sister left. She meets Merc, the head of the gang or organisation called the "Runners". He trains her in the art of.. well.. running, and using the rooftops of the city to their advantage. Essentially they are what one could call delivery people (don't quote me on that, I played it early morning so I don't remember much of the beginning).After a short parcour and CQC tutorial you're being thrown right into the game, the only help you get is the so called "Runner's Vision" giving you hints on where to go. Even with this help I was sometimes struggling to find the correct pathway, even though the levels are mostly linear, only giving you no more than a few ways from one area to the next.Personally I really enjoyed the game. My only problem was incredible FPS drops in areas with shattered glas or when I've been shot at. To fix this you have to delete a folder and two files from the game files because those are outdated drivers which EA included for some ♥♥♥♥ing stupid reason.Anyway, you should really give this classic a try because even on the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥ computers (my laptop is from 2011) you can play this game on maximum settings and it looks absolutely beautiful.

												Mirror's Edge, when it "works", is a fun game.  The ability to run, slide, leap and climb feels wonderful when it comes together.  The story is pretty "meh" but you don't play ME for the story.Where it falls apart is the difficulty of executing some of the moves.  I'm not used to playing platformers so maybe this is on me, but there were lots of places where I jumped, died, jumped, died, jumped, died, .... etc.  Until somehow, thru what seemed like sheer luck, I happened to hit it right.   There were one or two jumps where I'm absolutely sure I was executing them right, but until I invoked "bullet time" (or whatever it's called) they didn't work.  Even worse, in some cases the game sends you back to an earlier checkpoint where you then get to execute a couple of other finicky moves.  Yes, I did get better at it, but a few things like wall running felt hit or miss the whole way thru.  That stuff turned what would have been a fun runthru into an exercise in exasperated persistence.All that being said, it is a fun game, just be prepared to get annoyed.

												I first played this game back in 2009 when it came out and I still play it to this very day from time to time.Gameplay is smooth with the perfect mix of realism and arcade elements to still make it a game. It really feels like you flow through the levels, quickly fight back (or escape) an enemy and get back on track running towards your goal. The game has also some of the greatests vistas of urban landscapes I have ever witnessed in a videogame. The level design is remarkably beautiful to date.Some negative aspects I could drag your attention to are its lenght and the way the story is presented. The game is short, no doubt. Although it offers a certain level or replayability because of its open level design, each time you play it you will finish it faster (but we can say that about just any game, can't we?). As for the story, it feels like it is just there; a filler that gives you a reason to run from point A to point B. But you do not really get into it and what you actually do in the game does not feel too much related to its further development.However, I do not think they are game breaking or that the experience suffers as a whole from these two elements, otherwise I would not have been playing it for the past 5 years, let alone recommend it.

content:
11, 2016
#1 Reason you should buy this game: you can look down and see your feet.Mirror's Edge (let's just call it Edge), was EA's bold idea to try something new. And it worked out really well (we are not talking about the slight failure Catalyst is). Edge tells us the story of Faith, definitely not a reference to the leap of faith, a runner in an unnamed city almost completely devoid of personality and full of order, absolute control and sparkly clean buildings, thanks to its totalitarian leaders. Faith as a runner, delivers special packages that contain information to an underground network that seek to undermine the authorities. And the best way to do that, is parkour.The story is pretty mediocre, at best. Characters are dull and not interesting, full of cliches and devoid of any emotional ties to the player. They simply are there to serve their role and that's it. The cutscenes are similar to really bad street sign commercials, trying to get in touch with "modernism", but they fail to do so, and personally, they simply deprived me of any enjoyment to watch. At least, the story doesn't last long, leaving you to enjoy your second playthrough.At least the world is interesting to explore. The art style and the minimalistic colors help to understand what over-bearing goverment means. You can almost feel the concrete blasting heat all over the place as you traverse pipes, fences and wall-run to your goal. It's beautiful, but the limited choice of colors can make you feel a bit frustrated after a while, thinking that the city is in fact, the same neighbourhood redone over and over again to fill in the maps with small tweaks. I can look past that though. They could allow the players to freely roam though, not simply constraint them to small parts of the city in each stage. Shame they didn't come up with this idea.The gameplay however, is the true star of the show. Faith will slam doors with her hand, her feet will kick during a long jump, the motion blur on the sides, they all come together to create an incredible level of immersion and momentum, making you gasp for breath as you leap through the gaps between skyscrapers, uncertain whether you survive the jump or not. At times, squads of policemen will chase you and you have the options to avoid them, or grab one of their guns and fight them. However, hand-to-hand and gunfights are your only options and they feel slightly clunky at times, since punches and kicks are very redundant and to perform a weapon steal you need to wait for the right moment when the weapon becomes red.After the campaign, there's not really much you can do. You can pop up the difficulty and try the challenges, but that's about it. There is no multiplayer, but there are leaderboards where you can test your skills against other people, but never in direct, straightforward competition.It's a nice game, it's worth giving a shot since it's something you don't see everyday. You won't regret it.RATING:Gameplay: 8/10Presentation: 8/10Story: 4/10Unique Factor: Detailed Animations: 8.5/10OVERALL:7.1/10

er 28, 2016
												Revolutionary back in the day and still pleasant to play. The main gameplay revolves around freerunning a futuristic and superb looking city, getting from Point A to Point B as efficient as possible, with a little martial arts and gunfights thrown in here and there. The game is set in a city, where the police is in control of everything and sharing free information has become almost impossible. The runners are the ones transporting them illegally for their customers high above the city. You play such a runner and it doesn't take long until you get in trouble with the law and may discover something bigger along the way.The gameplay is fast and is only slowed down by some combat sequences. You can either solve them with your fists or overwhelm an officer and use his gun, but most of the time you will be evading the cops with your freerunning skills. It is not an open world game, your path is linear with a few possible variations. Combat is the weakest part of the game, followed by the story, which basically only exists to give you a reason to run to a certain point and is fairly short. Afterwards you can play the levels in time trial mode or try and find all hidden collectibles throughout the levels.Sometimes you need to find the correct path and the game feels like a puzzler. If you are not surrounded by police and can take your time to figure things out, those parts are really enjoyable. If you're under heavy fire and have to act quickly and constantly chose dead ends or wrong jumps, because you don't have the time to study your surroundings, it can get a bit frustrating. content:
ry 14, 2016
												Mirror's Edge is a very original game which became an instant classic because of its innovations and timeless charm.What makes the game original is the complete focus on running and navigating the environment without having to deal with puzzles, combat or other distractions.You play as "Faith", a runner, in a beautiful yet dystopic city, where the goverment constantly monitors its citizens and oppresses the freedom of information; your goal is to deliver sensitive data and uncover a conspiracy that revoles around the main character sister's framing. The whole game relies on a constant "flow" of movement; the more you run the faster you go and you're encouraged to link jumps, wallruns, slides and rolls like you would in a fighting game, in order to maintain some kind of a combo.As soon as you start it becomes incredibly addictive, and you'll soon challenge yourself at being faster, faster and faster.The thing that separates this game from the rest, other than the simple yet perfect gameplay, is the masterful level design; the city you play in has an incredible charm, with its candid roads and silver skyscrapers and the developers really put a lot of though into the design of the map. Whenever you are not runnin you'll spend countless minutes enjoying the scenary and daydreaming about how living in such a place must be like, and the specific use of primary colors for the interiors makes a nice contrast to the bright white outdoors; everything is clean, perfect, symmetric, simple.The path you have to follow is linear, but that allowed the developers to craft the most interesting way ever to navigate the environment, showing an insight into the life of the city, making the player visit its underground stations, offices, sewers, police headquarters, rooftops ecc...It's very hard to describe this with words and you really have to play it to witness it.One thing that's fair to admit it's the game's lenght; realistically you'll finish the campaign in about 5 hours or less, which for me never was a problem but i know for many others could.There's not much else to say about the game, because of its genius semplicity, other than it's a masterpiece; a game that every gamer worthy of this title should experience, to make its cult status grow even bigger.A game like this is only made every 10 years or so, it rightfully became a cult classic.

er 19, 2014
												I finally got around to beating this game after like two years. I got about 2/3 of the way done before, got stuck on an area, got salty, and quit. Picked it up again and finished it in 3 hours or so.It's usually not hard to see WHERE you're supposed to end up, it's just finding the path there and not falling to your death from a bad jump. I'd say there's replay value, because as soon as you finish the game you're just really getting the mechanics down and tend to make less mistakes.I see a lot of people complain about combat - I sort of get it, the combat isn't exactly fun but it's also not the point of the game in my opinion. You're a runner. You should be avoiding every enemy you can and taking the others out with acrobatic grace. Should be, anyway. I suck at disarming enemies so I just had to punch folks until they fell down. It was underwhelming, but I also think being chased and attacked was necessary to the feeling you get while running away. Glass crashing around you and bullets flying, Faith escapes again into the corners of the city.I adored the art style and selective use of colors. People saying it's all red and white are blind or didn't actually play the game. The colors do a lot of foreshadowing and kind of mentally prep you for upcoming events. I plan on doing some speed trials just to get pretty screenshots.PhysX is a turd and will blow your computer up, even if you have a PhysX optimized GPU. If you get huge FPS drops when windows break, it's PhysX. Disable it and enjoy the game.It's so easy to not notice the soundtrack. A lot of the time you're just being talked to via headset, or you hear the sounds of the city. But there are a couple areas where the song is inspiring, where it makes you feel like you're flying and the air is rushing past your ears and through your hair.The story is so-so. Think 90's action flick and you've got an idea of it. There are a couple plot holes but they're pretty easy to overlook and don't affect the enjoyment of the game for me personally. I just wanna jump off walls and do cool stuff.If you're into acrobatic gameplay and using speed rather than force, definitely give this game a shot. It's fun and the style is so memorable.

Mirror's Edge is a game built solely on free running/parkour and fleeing from a new government's regime.This includes reaching your destinations in unusual ways through roofs, obstacles and other wide or narrow spaces. All of this often leads to an encounter with armed forces which sometimes can be avoided or challenged through a combat.★ Movement has a good flow until you reach combat. 												A game for people who wish they could do the stunts they see on YouTube. Pros -Stunning graphics for a 2009 game, especially the models. Everything you look at is beautiful, especially the environments.-Very fun parkour system(with a learning curve), that makes you want to come back for more. By far the highlight of this game, you can do a variety of different parkour moves that tie together smoothly and fluidly.-Great soundtrack that perfectly captures the modern/sci-fi world of Mirror's Edge.-Interesting level design that captures the creativity to do parkour.-The mechanics itself feel realistic. There were few times that it felt as though I shouldn't have survived something or shouldn't have been able to jump that far. And in places where I don't survive, it makes sense. A young woman in nothing but a tanktop and sweatpants wouldn't be able to survive 3 point blank headshots from an automatic weapon. Cons -textures show flaw at times, but on very few objects-Campaign that falls flat. This is the biggest gripe with this game that I have. I didn't feel invested in many of the characters, and I only wanted to go through the story because the parkour itself was fun, and the ending was very disappointing. I particularly didn't enjoy the animated cutscenes, but that's simply personal preference.-The game fluctuates from rather simple to extremely difficult. I turned off "runner vision", which lets you see what objects to run/jump/climb onto next, and at times I didn't think it would've been possible to do WITH runner vision. -The combat felt extremely clunky, and in the late game, AI could kill you extremely fast. At least an hour of my 7-hour run through of the game was spent redoing combat sections because the AI killed me too damn fast and I didn't know how to go about the situation.-Fair share of bugs. Nothing much. TL;DR/Conclusion An experimental, revolutionary game that takes the art of parkour and implements it perfectly into a game's setting. It's innovations pay off with stunning visuals, fun mechanics, and an immersive, beautiful atmosphere. This game is a cult classic that should be played before you die. However, don't expect much from story, and prepare to be frustrated at various aspects of the game.7 out of 10. Great game

Anyway, like most of other reviewers, i have to select NO, unfortunately, this game is a "yes, but.." kind of game. 												Mirror's Edge is one of those games that was made a few years ago, but still wipes the floor with most recent games. Don't let EA's involvement in the game throw you off, this one was from before the dark days that give us nightmares every night.While the storyline of the game is not amazing, it is still pretty decent and is still more interesting than a lot of storylines in current games. The main appeal of this game for me was the apparent freedom of movement you have, even though the levels are quite linear. The wide-open level design makes you feel like the path you take is not necessarily the one and only path through the level, even though most of the time it is. The time trial levels reuse some of the storyline levels, which makes them somewhat repetitive yet familliar in an environment where practising easily makes you more comfortable with the section you are running.The freerunning mechanics don't feel clunky and with the focus on momentum, they feel really fast and smooth when you are playing well and have a reasonable drop in this when you are not (which still does not make the freerunning feel clunky).Considering the game was released in 2009 for PC, you don't need one of those new-fangled super-toaster 5000 with four bread slots and fast-defrost action- glueing a few potatoes together should suffice. Since the game is over five years old, it is pretty cheap now, too. Unless you don't like this kind of game, there isn't much argument for not giving it a go.

												Fight or flight: a physiological reaction that occurs in response to a perceived harmful event, attack, or threat to survival. There, i just summarized the gameplay in Mirror's Edge. And the "simplicity" of it is perhaps the main strenght in this gloriously original game. You either fight, or flight(run). Or preferably both. It's as simple as that. And it will honestly take you quite a few tries overcoming both enemies and obstacles in your way. I've experienced my fair share of deaths, and especially when you first start out, it can all seem overwhelming. But with every death comes a lesson learned, and hopefully after a few tries you will manage to both run and fight seamlessly without any mistakes or hiccups. And when you accomplish this, it feels like you can take on the whole world(or at least the city's policeforce). There are multiple ways from A to B and the controls are solid(with a controller, never tried keyboard). When you're not being chased or bullets don't fly in your direction, you also get parts in the game where the road you must take isn't always as clear. Normally, you posess something called runner's vision, which visually guides you through the game in the form of the color red(red boxes, planks, doors). But some areas in the game unfolds like a puzzle. You stop up, think, do, die and retry. A welcoming break, in which you also can take into account the amazing visuals or beautifully crafted locations in the game.Perhaps it is the visually stunning graphics/animations that is the main strenght? It took me quite a long time to finally play this game, i think its close to 3 years. And its too bad and clearly long overdue. The animations are quite smooth, from the fight sequences to the parkour element. The areas are intelligently crafted which in some cases reward your curiosity. And running from cops wielding assault rifles or helicopters with machineguns has never been so adrenaline pumping. Especially when you take leap of faiths and float through the air in what feels like an eternity, all while the sun is shining in your eyes. Soundtrack is another major plus with this game, with a special mention going to the end sountrack. Overall the soundtrack enchances the gameplay and visuals of the game with a exhilarating sound which fills you  with adrenaline during some of the most intense chase sequences. This game isn't without some flaws though. Albeit the story isn't necessarily bad, it't only enough there to keep you somewhat invested as you enjoy the other brilliant aspects of this game. The campaign is also quite short, in which i completed it in about 5 hours. Fear not though, as there are other gamemodes to keep you occupied, such as timetrial. The highest difficulty level also unlocks when you complete the game once, so that may inspire you to go for a round 2. I'm not a fan of giving out a rating in terms of numbers, but i can definitely recommend this game. A truly innovative game in terms of gameplay and visuals(for its time), with an amazing soundtrack to boot. This game can be aquired dirt cheap, and give you an adrenaline kick in your otherwise uneventful life.Still alive.

												Mirror's Edge is a beautiful game. It's fast paced and doesn't have to ever slow down if you are a good enough free-runner. But, this game isn't perfect, and as a hug fan of this game I'm going to be completely honest.The good things about Mirror's Edge:The Look - The City is amazingly gorgeous and dynamic. Different color schemes for certain buildings really help piece the city together.The Feel - The controls are decent enough to get you where you need to go without looking like an idiot, but it's the animations and the lightweight feel of Faith that really make you feel like a runner. The way she vaults and slides across the floor look fantastic.The Soundtrack - One of my favorite videogame OST's, Mirror's Edge has a distinctive feel that's core comes from listening to it's music. The Bad things about Mirror's Edge:Wonky parkour controls - At times you'll find that what you want to pull off isn't achievable unless you're a skilled pro at the game. You want to wall run then coil over that fence? Until you're completely familarized with the controls you'll fail 90% of the time.No Achievements - You wanted to get achievements and cards for your amazing parkouring in this game? You would be better off buying it on console. That's right, Steam doesn't offer any achievements or trading cards for this game. Probably because the game is so old, the port to Steam is missing a lot of things that would make playing Mirror's Edge worth your while.The combat - Now, this is completely avoidable if you have the skill to evade the police, but the combat isn't all that great. Sure, when you have the chance to pull of wallrun-kicks and leap onto SWAT members it can be enjoyable. But the areas at which you face the police are so open and empty you'll end up walking up to them, waiting for them to hit you with a melee attack, and easily tapping a button and countering them. Then you'll drop their gun, rinse, and repeat this process until all of the police are taken down and you can get on your way.Short storyline - The story is pretty uninteresting in my opinion. It only picks up at certain parts, and it's easy to tell who the villain is going to be by the final chapters. The game is only 9 missions long, and these missions are usually 10 - 30 minutes long. In the end, Mirror's Edge is a great game that you will enjoy if you're into parkour and first person combat games. But if you want rewards, achievements, cards, or badges, steer clear of this title. By the end of the game, you'll feel one of two emotions. Satisfied with a great short-but-sweet experience, or you'll be left wanting more out of the game, since you can only now speed-run the same sections of the game or do time trials on certain parts of missions. Also, mentioning the no achievements you'll feel like you just sped-ran the whole game and all of the time trials for nothing, seeing how your scores on the leaderboard are only going to be buried beneath hackers of the game.6/10 - Good but could be a lot better if Steam supported the features that other titles have on it's store.

content:

												Very short, (I beat the storyline in 5 hours) but very fun.  Picked it up for $5 on sale and it was absolutely worth it.The movement is amazing.  With about half a dozen techniques to use, you can approach most of the game from a variety of (literal) angles.  There's also a time trial mode to really test yourself.What little combat there is is intentionally clunky as you're a "runner" not a "fighter."  But if you master the movement, you can do some amazing combat techniques too.  I, however, settled on repeatedly doing a running slide and kicking every single opponent in the junk over and over.  Crude, yet effective.The platforming never felt "cheap" like in a lot of platformers, where you need nearly pixel-perfect precision.  In this game, if you're having trouble with a jump it's more than likely you're using the wrong techniques.There's not much to the story, so don't expect anything wonderful there.  Someone wronged you, you're trying to figure out who they are and why they did it.  Nothing epic or grandiose like saving the world, it's pretty much just personal revenge with a bit of a political background.I had a few minor issues, including one slowdown/crash that was remedied by simply turning off PhysX in the options.  Other issues were my character not grabbing ledges that I clearly thought she should, or at one point I must have "stubbed my toe" mid wall-run because I just stopped and fell off the wall.Due to the extremely short length of the game, I can only recommend picking it up on sale.  It has difficulty settings, time trials, and some collectible items, so there's a small bit of replay value to it.

												Ever heard of a first person platformer? Not really, no. So that's a pretty wide gap to bridge. Mirror's Edge does a nice job to jump the gap, but it sure is no bridge.Mirror's Edge puts you in the bright red shoes of Faith, an inhabitant of an Orwellesque city who runs and jumps on rooftops to deliver secret packages to people who try to liberate the population from the regime. The premise is interesting, but the game refrains from giving you a clear motive or goal; it just drip-feeds it to you. It is not paced very well. You don't really understand what you're doing until the credits roll. Call it Chekov writing if you must, I call it demotivational. The controls are simple, yet effective. This isn't like platforming in Half Life where pressing the jump button launches you into space and pushing up to ladders makes you go up; this is about momentum and clever jumps and acrobatics. The freerunning is done fluently and intuitively. However, your runner's high tends to be tackled by the game's awkward and completely redundant combat system. It is a shame cause it would have been so much more fun if you could just...keep on running. You run through a weird city that is coloured white and then some other colours. It looks very stylish and makes it pleasant to look at while you jump from building to building. Mirror's Edge has an interesting concept going for it, but it seems to lack refinement and pacing. Still, it's worth a shot just for the experience of FPS running.

												Very short, (I beat the storyline in 5 hours) but very fun.  Picked it up for $5 on sale and it was absolutely worth it.The movement is amazing.  With about half a dozen techniques to use, you can approach most of the game from a variety of (literal) angles.  There's also a time trial mode to really test yourself.What little combat there is is intentionally clunky as you're a "runner" not a "fighter."  But if you master the movement, you can do some amazing combat techniques too.  I, however, settled on repeatedly doing a running slide and kicking every single opponent in the junk over and over.  Crude, yet effective.The platforming never felt "cheap" like in a lot of platformers, where you need nearly pixel-perfect precision.  In this game, if you're having trouble with a jump it's more than likely you're using the wrong techniques.There's not much to the story, so don't expect anything wonderful there.  Someone wronged you, you're trying to figure out who they are and why they did it.  Nothing epic or grandiose like saving the world, it's pretty much just personal revenge with a bit of a political background.I had a few minor issues, including one slowdown/crash that was remedied by simply turning off PhysX in the options.  Other issues were my character not grabbing ledges that I clearly thought she should, or at one point I must have "stubbed my toe" mid wall-run because I just stopped and fell off the wall.Due to the extremely short length of the game, I can only recommend picking it up on sale.  It has difficulty settings, time trials, and some collectible items, so there's a small bit of replay value to it.

												Mirror's Edge is one of those games that was made a few years ago, but still wipes the floor with most recent games. Don't let EA's involvement in the game throw you off, this one was from before the dark days that give us nightmares every night.While the storyline of the game is not amazing, it is still pretty decent and is still more interesting than a lot of storylines in current games. The main appeal of this game for me was the apparent freedom of movement you have, even though the levels are quite linear. The wide-open level design makes you feel like the path you take is not necessarily the one and only path through the level, even though most of the time it is. The time trial levels reuse some of the storyline levels, which makes them somewhat repetitive yet familliar in an environment where practising easily makes you more comfortable with the section you are running.The freerunning mechanics don't feel clunky and with the focus on momentum, they feel really fast and smooth when you are playing well and have a reasonable drop in this when you are not (which still does not make the freerunning feel clunky).Considering the game was released in 2009 for PC, you don't need one of those new-fangled super-toaster 5000 with four bread slots and fast-defrost action- glueing a few potatoes together should suffice. Since the game is over five years old, it is pretty cheap now, too. Unless you don't like this kind of game, there isn't much argument for not giving it a go.

content:

												Fight or flight: a physiological reaction that occurs in response to a perceived harmful event, attack, or threat to survival. There, i just summarized the gameplay in Mirror's Edge. And the "simplicity" of it is perhaps the main strenght in this gloriously original game. You either fight, or flight(run). Or preferably both. It's as simple as that. And it will honestly take you quite a few tries overcoming both enemies and obstacles in your way. I've experienced my fair share of deaths, and especially when you first start out, it can all seem overwhelming. But with every death comes a lesson learned, and hopefully after a few tries you will manage to both run and fight seamlessly without any mistakes or hiccups. And when you accomplish this, it feels like you can take on the whole world(or at least the city's policeforce). There are multiple ways from A to B and the controls are solid(with a controller, never tried keyboard). When you're not being chased or bullets don't fly in your direction, you also get parts in the game where the road you must take isn't always as clear. Normally, you posess something called runner's vision, which visually guides you through the game in the form of the color red(red boxes, planks, doors). But some areas in the game unfolds like a puzzle. You stop up, think, do, die and retry. A welcoming break, in which you also can take into account the amazing visuals or beautifully crafted locations in the game.Perhaps it is the visually stunning graphics/animations that is the main strenght? It took me quite a long time to finally play this game, i think its close to 3 years. And its too bad and clearly long overdue. The animations are quite smooth, from the fight sequences to the parkour element. The areas are intelligently crafted which in some cases reward your curiosity. And running from cops wielding assault rifles or helicopters with machineguns has never been so adrenaline pumping. Especially when you take leap of faiths and float through the air in what feels like an eternity, all while the sun is shining in your eyes. Soundtrack is another major plus with this game, with a special mention going to the end sountrack. Overall the soundtrack enchances the gameplay and visuals of the game with a exhilarating sound which fills you  with adrenaline during some of the most intense chase sequences. This game isn't without some flaws though. Albeit the story isn't necessarily bad, it't only enough there to keep you somewhat invested as you enjoy the other brilliant aspects of this game. The campaign is also quite short, in which i completed it in about 5 hours. Fear not though, as there are other gamemodes to keep you occupied, such as timetrial. The highest difficulty level also unlocks when you complete the game once, so that may inspire you to go for a round 2. I'm not a fan of giving out a rating in terms of numbers, but i can definitely recommend this game. A truly innovative game in terms of gameplay and visuals(for its time), with an amazing soundtrack to boot. This game can be aquired dirt cheap, and give you an adrenaline kick in your otherwise uneventful life.Still alive.

												I had always heard good things about Mirror's Edge and it's amazing gameplay, but I never had the opportunity to try it for myself. One new computer later, and one of the first games I bought was Mirror's Edge. The free-flowing parkour system is the first thing you notice about this game and it works so well. The controls and the animation of Hope work freely with the player and the game allows you to pull off some sick moves across ridiculous distances. The music accompaning the parkour fits well and the enviornment is beautiful and slick. The red guidance system, while it does not always work, is very helpful and it really helps to drive the momentum of the game. The story is pretty good, and it keeps the levels relevant and with purpose. My issue with the game is that some jumps don't work the first time sometimes, leading to some frustrating deaths. That and the combat is not very well-implemented and it almost helps to try to run past combat encounters than to engage them. Overall, Mirror's Edge is a great parkour action game that is an experience that you won't be able to play many other places. Despite some weird jumps and the mediocre combat sections, Mirror's Edge is a great game to own, and I have a sub-par computer, so it will run even if your computer is not up to standard.

												8/10This game is super fun, super beautiful, and also really hard. There are lots of different elements of parkour and fighting that come into play, keeping it from being monotonous as you try to uncover the secret plots of the government. The cutscenes have their own distinctive art style, really making this game one of a kind. The textures and objects are fairly simple, but it adds to the futuristic environment and makes the parkour more straightforward. Despite the appearance of a massive world, you can always tell what you are supposed to do due to color coding of useful objects and also pressing alt lets you look where you need to go in most places. You do all sorts of crazy stuff like climb down stormpipes, hop from train to train, jump from one crane to another, and use a helicopter to swing to freedom. This game is definitely worth any investment of time and money. Although this game was on the shorter side, I really enjoyed my time and can't wait for the sequel.

content:
27, 2014
												One of the most original games of recent years. I would never have guessed that a developer company would some day release an FPS game where the emphasis would be on running, sliding, jumping, vaulting, rolling, crouching and all this done on the rooftops of skyscrapers. These are the movements your protagonist, Faith, uses whenever she is faced with an obstacle.The game is an unstoppable roller coaster ride. All the movements you do you do while running. And to make it more exciting the game does not want you to stop - your "vision" enables you to see certain objects, ramps, ledges and pipes highlighted in red so you know you can interact with these objects and you do not need to stop to look for clues. Later on as the game gets gradually more difficult this assistance is reduced and you can even turn it off completely so that the game can offer you the ultimate challenge.Enemies can be taken down with melee combat but most of the time you need to run. Those that have weapons can easily eliminate you. Interestingly, you can knock out some of these police officers and pick up their weapons. Bear in mind that the ammo is limited so once your magazine is empty you should get rid of your firearm. But with weapons you want to aim like in a true FPS game, right? So, using a firearm will break the pace here, therefore, it's best to just skip this opportunity and run all the way till the game ends.And pretty much that is the only problem with Mirror's Edge. You run fast and you reach the end fast. They could have included some extra chapters to make the game longer. You have time trial challenges so that you can keep playing stages over and over again improving your total time for completion.  I really wish, however, if there was a sequel to this game as it was such an exciting ride. It would be really nice to be a courier again in the new era of next-gen games.

												Mirror’s Edge is one of my all time favorite games, I’ve played through it multiple time on the xbox and twice now on my PC and it never gets boring. The controls and gameplay are damn near perfect when it comes to running and jumping, once you get past the training level most of the moves you do feel natural and the game does a great job of telling you when to do what without being super obvious and still allowing for improvisation. It gets your heart pounding and makes you feel like a badass and is just genuinely really fun. But the game isn’t perfect, the most obvious thing to point out is the forced gun combat. It feels like it was added as an afterthought because the publisher wanted a more action packed game, and by action packed I mean more guns, and it never felt as intuitive or as fun as the running parts of the game. Another disappointment was the story, it’s just not well written and it’s way too short. If they hired a team of great writers to write Mirror’s Edge the game could have easily become a classic. But those are minor things, the bottom line is that this game really ♥♥♥♥ing fun to play.

												Lots of fun. While many people say it's not replayable, I've gone through the game a good ten times and enjoyed each run. Memorizing spots to speed up your runs that you may not have known existed during your first playthrough and seeing a great running combo pay off is very rewarding, which adds a sense of replayability to the game and also makes second and third runs faster and more fun.On the flip side, by giving players such an intensely graceful experience, after a few runs the player starts to play overly recklessly and hectically as they try to keep the flow going, which often results in death and frustration. Going fast for the whole level is incredibly addicting, and I hope Mirror's Edge 2 either adaps to or changes this. Give the player an incentive to ever stop going very quickly, like a decent combat system or a small chance to explore and see what the safest/fastest routes through a level are and make your choice. Otherwise, make sure the game flows as neatly as possible and feels graceful and fast the whole way.For what it is, Mirror's edge is definitely worth the buy, especially at $4.99, which I've seen it go for many times.

content:
, 2016
												Quick note about making this work on modern systems:1. The default PhysX setting will use outdated software and murders performance when the cops start shooting. There are several workarounds available on the game's PcGamingWiki page. Alternatively, just turn PhysX off.2. The in-game Vsync did not work (at least for me). I still got horrible tearing even with it enabled on my 60Hz monitor. Forcing adaptive Vsync in the Nvidia drivers worked perfectly.Once you get those issues fixed, it runs like a dream, and honestly it looks pretty great for a game from 2008. The bright, sunny, whitewashed world is a nice change of pace from the typical grimdark of many recent games. The city feels vibrant despite a relative lack of NPCs. Also, the good anisotropic filtering means that textures usually look pretty good (at least, they're not distractingly bad like they are in some 360-era games). The character modeling on the enemies is relatively weak and probably the biggest indication that this is a last-gen title.The gameplay itself is primarily first-person platforming with occasional combat mixed in. The platforming is the stronger element - nailing a free-flowing parkour section is exhilarating. Early in the game, the platforming is quite easy, so you can gain a lot of speed and you start to feel like you're flying. It's amazing. Some later levels have much tougher platforming sections that break up the momentum a bit (at least on your first playthrough), but successfully navigating them is still extremely satisfying (and once you've figured them out you can speedrun them to feel even cooler). There's also one boss fight that's a little bit stupid, but it's thankfully short.Overall, despite the occasional moments of frustration, Mirror's Edge is a unique and frequently breathtaking game that's worth a buy for both FPS and platformer fans.

												Mirror's edge is uniquely frustrating. The aesthetic is wonderful; the cyberpunk city, the intriguing story, the beautifully rendered scenery. However the gameplay left a lot to be desired. The game starts off well, the free running aspect of the game is very smooth and rewards skill. However even early on I found myself with no real sense of direction, and I lost track of the amount of times I yelled "Well where the HELL am I supposed to go now?" in frustration. It's a real shame because Mirror's Edge has so much going for it, but I honestly can'y recommend it unless you pick it up for a greatly reduced price. I've heard the sequel is superior. We shall see.

content:
r 6, 2015
												TL;DR : Skip to conclusion.Mirror's Edge, a First Person Action game developed by DICE and published by EA. Although the game was released in 2009, it still has features that many games nowadays can't recreate.Story Introduction: You play as Faith Connors, an agile and deadly information carrier called "Runners". You live in a city that has been heavily monitored and is run by private security corporations. Also, your sister, Kate Connors, is framed to be a murderer of a mayor candidate named "Pope". You must save your sister and uncover the secrets that will bring harm not only to herself and Kate, but everyone she loves.Here are the game's Pros and Cons:Pros: The movement system: Mirror's Edge is known for it's parkour elements. You can scale walls, jump between buildings and even ziplining across skyscrapers!Combat: You can jumpkick, slidekick, and also disarm opponent's weapons. It is not hard nor easy.Scenery: It is simple, but yet beautiful. There are not much colors, like mostly I see white, red, green, blue, and black. Also, somehow, trees are white... but in this game, scenery is stunning to watch and explore.No UI Clutter: This game has just one small dot in the middle and the screen, and that's it. No ammo counter, no health bar, and you might ask how in the world am I going to know where to go? The answer is Runner Vision.Runner Vision: Some objects in the game, eg. stairs or pipes will turn red if you get close to them, it gives you a hint of where to go or do. Runner Vision is a very creative game design in my opinion, you don't need a waypoint with distance marker in this game, just the Runner Vision.You can always turn it off if you don't want it.Cons:Story: The story is tedious, the characters are okayish, and also it's very short. I beat the whole game in 4 hours! It is just too quick. However, I did not collect all the "Runner Bags" (Collectibles) that are scattered in every level though. I'll do that later.AI: The enemy shoots like stormtroopers, they do not have a good aim (at least in Easy and Normal difficulty), but their weapon damage is fair enough.Bugs and WTF moments: You will find some bugs and some WTF moments, but they are not to the point where you will rage.Conclusion: I loved this game, despite the flaws I can see that this is one of the best FPA games I've ever played. Parkour hasn't been so much fun in a videogame! I recommend that you get this game on sale if you want to parkour and shoot!

content:
25
												Man I have always loved this game.  The gameplay is exciting, and the art style is distinct and has it's own atmosphere that you can get immersed in.I've always been impressed at how they managed to make a game out of free-running, something that seems very organic and wouldn't lend itself very well to a video game, or at least very difficult to capture.  But they certainly achieved that, and in an interface that feels intuitive as well. It's very timing based - jump so that the top of the metal fence will be at the apex of your jump, and when she reaches it, she will gracefully vault over and maintain her momentum.   Press it too late and she'll jump and slam into it, hanging from the edge and pull herself up, climb over, and drop down to a standstill, so you have to build up your momentum again.   It's genius, that it "makes sense" to you physically and feels right, and yet is also an enjoyable game mechanic.You can steal an enemy's gun and breifly engage in FPS gameplay.  Very briefly, because you will never pick up new ammo for the gun, she will cast it away when it's spent.  I liked this, it made for some really bad-♥♥♥ moments and opened up other ways to get out of a situation, still using your parkour abilities to out maneuver the enemy.  For better or for worse they removed this in the sequel Mirror's Edge Catalyst, and I can't agree or disagree with that.  They want to keep it purely about parkour, and have a legitimate sounding explanation (the weapons are high-tech and bio-locked to the owner).  So you don't get the thrill of an FPS session, but more focus is put on the parkour, and they go into more detail with it there too.You MUST have an nVidia graphics card when you play this version of the game.  This will enable PhysX and a lot of "dressing" will be enabled in the levels.  On paper this might sound superficial, but it really heightens the action.  A mini gun on a helecopter rips the tarp in front of you to shreds as it opens fire, tattered cloth blowing away in the wind.  Shards of glass rain down around your ears as the enemy shoots at you while you run through a hallway with tall glass windows.  Don't underestimate the emotional impact this effect has.  I played it on an AMD card and forgot about it, then wondered why the game felt so empty and lifeless in the action sequences I previously remember playing.  When I looked into it, I got my education on PhysX, and was so annoyed I immediately sold my AMD card and got an nVidia one again.  (This has less relevance now since most games are console ports and devs can't justify putting effort into effects that a very small percentage of their user-base will see).I've had many movie-like moments in this game, that were completley born of the dynamic combat and free-running system.  It takes a very special game to achieve that.   Spend time learning the controls and making them second nature, and you have a really good game with an exciting story, for very cheap now.  I personally believe the art style holds up, even if it may appear a bit flat and lacking detail by modern gaming standards.  That was 2009 remember, and they did a damn good job.

												Mirror's edge is an interesting tale of free-runners (parkour, if you will) be sort of rebels in a city overran by corruption, "law enforcement", and conspiracy. You play this female freerunner whose sister somehow gotten herself involved in a giant conspiracy, and you need to run through a gauntlet of cops, SWAT teams, and perhaps, other runners in your quest for truth and justice. As this is a first-person parkour game, you will be vaulting fences, guard rails, making death defying jumps between buildings, zipline across cables, wallruning between platforms sliding under some obstacles, as well as do some unarmed combat where you take guns away from cops and such (optional, this is NOT a shooter). There are plenty of challenges, and the game has a way to ease you into it by having a rooftop training course. Then it's balls to walls time as you're being chased by everybody... cops, SWAT, even helicopters. The idea is to chain together moves smoothly to get maximum speed, and it's not easy. But it's quite satisfying, as it's a very unique game.

												Man I have always loved this game.  The gameplay is exciting, and the art style is distinct and has it's own atmosphere that you can get immersed in.I've always been impressed at how they managed to make a game out of free-running, something that seems very organic and wouldn't lend itself very well to a video game, or at least very difficult to capture.  But they certainly achieved that, and in an interface that feels intuitive as well. It's very timing based - jump so that the top of the metal fence will be at the apex of your jump, and when she reaches it, she will gracefully vault over and maintain her momentum.   Press it too late and she'll jump and slam into it, hanging from the edge and pull herself up, climb over, and drop down to a standstill, so you have to build up your momentum again.   It's genius, that it "makes sense" to you physically and feels right, and yet is also an enjoyable game mechanic.You can steal an enemy's gun and breifly engage in FPS gameplay.  Very briefly, because you will never pick up new ammo for the gun, she will cast it away when it's spent.  I liked this, it made for some really bad-♥♥♥ moments and opened up other ways to get out of a situation, still using your parkour abilities to out maneuver the enemy.  For better or for worse they removed this in the sequel Mirror's Edge Catalyst, and I can't agree or disagree with that.  They want to keep it purely about parkour, and have a legitimate sounding explanation (the weapons are high-tech and bio-locked to the owner).  So you don't get the thrill of an FPS session, but more focus is put on the parkour, and they go into more detail with it there too.You MUST have an nVidia graphics card when you play this version of the game. First person parkour gaming at its finest.Short versionRun around, get creative on how to get from A to B using parkour tactics while avoiding enemies that attack you. What's not to like?Long versionThe story is a bit weak and predictable with some big plot holes and on the short side but you are not going to care about that. You'll be too busy running around the city map missions using creative ways to get around, under and above obstacles. Enemies can be avoided, fought or just killed; it's up to you. The PC version does not have the trophies achievements from the console versions, you will unlock everything by just finishing the game on any difficulty. So go nuts and kill if you want, there is no penalty or Steam achievements.The game uses checkpoints, but they are not located far from each other so no frustrating long re-attempts at difficult points.The stage designs.....GORGEOUS!!!  Bright clean colors and great architecture. Even background (or rather the far ground floor looking down from skyscrapers) has actual people and traffic life to it. You don't feel like you're in a dead city. Even birds and airplanes are sometimes visible in the sky. Seriously, who ever made the maps, is a genius. I really enjoyed just being there like it is a real city. The atmosphere alone is totally worth playing this game.

												Fantastic game.The game mechanics were fluid. The art style and soundtrack was beautiful. The story is debatable. Some find in cliche, others don't. I personally thought it was fine. The game is somewhat shorter than what you might expect, but the game itself has a lot of replayability. There are "Race/Speedrun" and "timetrial" versions of each level that aim to please players.Some describe the levels linear - as opposed to an open world - but I find that Mirror's Edge levels lies somewhere in between. Yes, objectives can be as simple as "Getting from Point A to Point B" but I believe the beauty is this game is that there are so many different routes to take to get to your objectives. Which is why I advice you to turn off "Runner's Vision" in the options. "Runner's Vision" is the guide to the game, showing you just ONE way to get to the objective. I feel the game is more fun when you discover these routes yourselves and develop your own "Runner's Vision" without the game doing it for you.I Already finished the main campaign but I'll be playing it again in the future. Then I'm off to it's sequel "Mirror's Edge: Catalyst" 10/10

content:
er 29, 2016
												Mirror's Edge is a phenomenal action platformer. The feeling of satisfaction you get when you land the perfect jump, disarm a cop, or slide kick a dude in the nuts is just tops. The story itself is fairly short, but the replay value seems to be pretty good. There's lots of stuff for you to find around the levels, and beyond that there's time trials and races with leaderboards, if you really want to see how fast you can blow through a level. The music and art are downright breathtaking at times, there was more than one moment where I had to stop running and just look out at the cityscape. Overall I loved this game, really glad I picked it up finally when it was on sale. The first few times I fell I winced and audibly gasped, it really sucks you in. The few hours it took to get through the story were incredibly exhilarating and visually stunning. Even the combat animations are just so incredibly smooth, you go from running along the side of a wall to twisting a dudes arm around and snatching his gun in a few seemingly effortless motions (if you get your timing right). Only played through once, on normal difficulty, and I found it pleasantly challenging to downright punishing at times. Some of the sparring with enemy NPCs was ridiculous, but after a few failed attempts I felt like a total badass taking them down. Highly recommend this game. Visually it's held up over the years, and mechanically it's one of the most thrilling games I've played. Parkour platforming and combat come together like peanut butter and chocolate in Mirror's Edge.

												Definetly worth getting. Its quite nice fast-paced puzzle/fps game- unlike in Portal series, you have to think fast, on the go, while bullets fly by your ears.You play as Faith Connors, female runner in futuristic city ruled by dictatorship. Runners serve as line of communications for those who want freedom back.Anyways, this is sadly where things go.. cliché. Faith's sister is framed for murder she didnt do and rest of game Faith tries to save her. Without spoiling (hopefully), on top of everything this has open ending, for sequel that still isnt announced (new Mirror's Edge is prequel).But despite story, its incredibly fun game. There are literally dozens of ways to reach your goal in every map, you can fight guards, you can avoid them, you can lure them into your trap. There is nothing like playing peek-a-boo with cops with shotguns near shipping crates for few hours (though AI is actually quite good).Be warned though, at first this might seem dull because its frankly very easy to play trough it but bloody hard to master, but when you do, you are going to play this for hours

												Surprisingly good game, I really enjoyed it despite its shortness (it takes about 5-7 hours to beat it, may be 10 hours with finding all collectives, but if you're interested in speedrun walkthrough, current world record is about 35 minutes with skipping all cut scenes and using all short cuts, if I'm not mistaken).Strong colours everywhere, protagonist is so full of life, whole city is beautiful(although a little empty on pedestrians), very immersive first person view, stylish 2d in game clips.Reminds me about Portal, where you have impressive (no sarcasm) running skills instead of portal gun. Climbing isn't as boring as in Assassin's creed, story is good too, although I find it a little unfinished.Levels are mix of running, labyrinth puzzles and fighting/running away from enemies. And some more running. Yes, even more on top of that.I enjoyed every minute of gameplay(except the time where I got stuck in puzzles)."Extras" menu in game allows you to check some beautiful concept arts, from early ones to the latest pre-release ones.The game worth the price even without discounts, that's a rare sight to see, for me at least, so I totally recommend anyone to grab it and spend at least few evenings playing it.

3, 2016
												Pros- Interesting genre: parcours with FPS. A lot of variety.  - You 'should' not get lost as both visual and audio clues help you to find your way to your goal.- Some parts of the games are without any clues. This allows you to be a bit creative and succeeding feels more rewarding. This is what games such as 'Remember Me' are lacking. - The controls are generally rather smooth...- ... and the FPS elements let you blow off some steam when the controls just fail. Because you die - a lot. - The respawn system works well. Really. - Stunning graphics and environments- Very fitting music- A great amount of detail in terms of random banter. Cons- The story. Only the surface of so many things has been scratched. No depth and the ending feels abrupt. - Basically no character development and everyone feels like a filler. You do not get attached to your heroine.- Controls are sometimes horrible for no reason whatsoever. Very, very annoying.- The odd balance between "a lot of help" and "no help whatsoever" in the parcours makes the game rather frustrating. - The combat system is difficult to master. Even slowing down time (your ability) makes it difficult to disarm ennemies. - Avoiding combat feels much better than actually fighting.- No replayability. No time trials. - Collectables are pointless as they do not unlock anything nor give any achievements.  - Audio quality sometimes sucks as most of the conversations happen through radio waves.  While you are being shot at by machine guns.- FPS Issues despite owning a Nvidia card. Disabling PhysX is mandatory. - Alt+Tab is a deathwish.I honestly did not enjoy this game. You might.

												Did I like this game? Not at first, no. It took a while to like it. My main problem with it? Nvidia. PhysX is awful. Its broken. It doesn't work. I spent the longest time trying to get the game to stop lagging and to stop screen-tearing. I gave up for a couple months, and eventually came back. This time I figured out what was wrong. It was PhysX. So I enabled v-sync and disabled PhysX. BAM, suddenly the game runs perfectly. BUT when you finally get into the game, its great. The running is a bit awkward, parts of the running and stuff seem unrealistic, however on the whole, its pretty awesome. You get to run around and jump and vault and wall-run and more. What I wish they'd fix is the combat. Its okay, I guess, but when you're trying to disarm, its a 50/50 for whether you can actually do it. Most of the time you're a split-second late or early, and the soldier kills you. You can take a few shots, but it gets to the point later in the game where you're getting killed what seems to be WAY too easily, compared to earlier in the game. The story is great if you're paying attention. It could be a lot better, they should have revealed more about what happened to the City and how its come to this awful state its in now, but instead they set all the focus on saving Kate. Its not bad, because its still a pretty great story, but it could be better and more indepth. I figure Mirror's Edge 2 (if it ever gets released, and if DICE doesn't ♥♥♥♥ it up) will have all that backstory.

												Mirror's Edge is a properly done 3d Sonic in disguise.If you are stopping to fight enemies, you did something wrong. In fact, if you are slowing down at all, you did something wrong.Much like in Sonic, speed is earned in Mirror's Edge. It's the reward for doing well. Are the levels linear? Yes. Does that make them bad? No. Does that make it so that there are no options? Heck no. If you play time trial mode, you'll quickly discover that you did the levels in the story mode all wrong- you were taking the wrong paths, timing your jumps badly, or otherwise screwing up.The occasional platforming puzzle can sometimes be frustrating, but if you're looking for a game about dodging gunfire as you wallrun, power-slide, vault, and just flat-out RUN, you've found the right title.Now hurry up with the damn sequel, DICE.

												I bought this game a couple day ago and finished it today. This is the first game in my entire library that I have finished. The free running in this game is simply superb, the run feels natural and the wall running for the most part is great. The graphics and art design are astounding accompanied with an awesome soundtrack which matches the intense parts with fast paced music and the calm parts with slow calm music. But the one major flaw in the game is the combat as many other fans will tell you. Now the idea of having to take other people's guns and having to work your way up the guns from a pistol to a submachine gun to a  shot gun and so on, theoretically would provide a nice idea. However the combat in this game does not please or deliver in those ideas, as the combat feels unbalanced, weirdly designed in both controls and gun handling as well as the power of weapons and enemies. However, for the most part you can avoid combat situations, but eventually you reach a point where repeatedly trying to steal a weapon through a quicktime event (as stealing guns from behind is a very rare occurence as the guards usually know where you are and immediately start shooting) becomes your only option. However the good very much overpowers the bad the story is intriguing but not too overbearing and if the gameplay doesn't meet you're tastes with great free running, the aesthetic design sure will.

content:
ber 18, 2014
												While I wouldn't go so far as to say this game is obscure, it certainly deserves more attention than it has received. I've never played anything quite like it. In fact, I'd like to say that Mirror's Edge is the best first-person parkour game I've ever played, but it's also the only first-person parkour game I've ever played. You know what? To hell with it. Mirror's Edge is the best first-person yada yada I've ever played, there you go. This game is something special and the experience of playing it, in spite of a few noteworthy imperfections, is awesome.The story takes place in a large sterile looking city where The Man has established a typical sort of Orwellian society with all the usual tropes therein. Granted, this is only really explained to you through flash animation-esque cutscenes, and never really explicitly shown. There are police here, like anywhere else, and you do have to avoid and occasionally fight them, but other than that, the air of oppression that they speak of is never really conveyed through the gameplay. All I see here is a society where the cops just really don't like you running around on the roof. The plot revolves around a conspiracy and, like many conspiracies, certain details don't really add up. Expecting a tight cohesive story out of this game is probably not something you should do.You play as Faith, a professional courier who conveys senstive items and information about the city via the art of parkour, flipping and jumping about far above the streets where the ubiquitous eye of big brother is ever watchful. Faith is an alright character. All those people who think video games are sexist might actually be okay with her. She's resourceful and athletic and determined and she also has normal sized cans, so women with average proportions don't have to be jealou- I mean, outraged at what a bunch of pigs the men who made this game are. She's also Asian, so if you're a creme colored frat boy with a weird fetish where you want to control a woman of the orient and make her do your chores and bear your children, this game is for you. I actually knew a guy in college who was like that. He constantly tried to make his American-born Vietnamese girlfriend come over and do his laundry. That relationship didn't last long. And no, he wasn't me. But I digress. Faith never does any of that, really. She's more of a sprint-up-the-wall-and-occasionally-murder-a-police-officer kind of chick.As far as the parkour in this game is concerned, the gameplay is fluid, intuitive, and uniquely excellent in its execution. The runners of the game, "runner" being the name prescribed to those of Faith's ilk, often expound upon the virtues of "flow," which I guess is sort of like the Force for these guys. It's the essence of what keeps their ninja mojo a goin'. This game actually has that: flow. Once you get over a moderately steep learning curve, you really develop a sort of intuitive feel for how to play this game well. It's pretty cool. The only downside is you might also start to feel a little ashamed of sitting in front of a computer for hours, pretending to be an extremely athletic person by pressing a series of buttons.What is a little lacking in Mirror's Edge is it's combat system. This is usually easy to forgive as combat is something best avoided 95% of the time. You are a runner, after all. However, you do have to engage in hand to hand combat and wield a gun occasionally. For lack of a better term/brain, the best way I can describe combat here is as "woogity," or maybe "rickety." You could even say its a little "finicky," or perhaps "mercurial." I guess what I'm trying to say is it feels pretty unnatural and inconsistant. It's basically the exact opposite of, well, everything else involved in playing this game. But that's okay, it's more or less functional and there's a good chance if you've decided to get into a gun fight, you should actually be running away anyway.One more thing, the atmosphere in Mirror's Edge is pretty cool. The people who made this thing did a whole lot with not very much as far as graphics are concerned. It's got a sort of over exposed, white washed, ultra clean sort of style, with lots of post modern angles and a stark ultilitarian urban sensibility or something. I should also add that the music is, like, real chill, bra. I mean, its nice, I really do like it. Sort of a nice mellow electronic thing going on there.Alright, so anyway, clearly I have too much time on my hands and IGN needs to hire me. Play this game, you won't regret it. You'll be hoping the sequel actually happens.

30, 2014
												Have you ever done a jumping puzzle in Counter Strike or TF2? This game, at its strongest is emulates that as its core game mechanic, with an increased sense of speed and sheer scale. For that alone, I've enjoyed playing it, and recommend it if at a bargain price. The drawbacks, however, are several. The story isn't captivating, and the characters are monotonic. The combat system when fighting police officers feels broken; I often feel as if I'm winning a fight by chance. Some of the more difficult levels push the boundaries of what can be done with the pre-incorporated moves, such as sliding on poles, climbing ladders, hanging off of railings, etc., and as a result can feel a little gimmicky. The levels are often on rails, where there is but one acceptable way to traverse the world. The emotional impact of falling was excellently captured by the dev team, but there's something taken away from it when you fall for the 12th time trying to do the exact same jump. This game is at its best in "race" mode, which eschews combat in favor of going for the fastest time through a progression. However, many of the race maps need to be unlocked by playing the campaign, and while many of the race maps are more open to route interpretation than the campaign maps, just as many are again "on rails." I conclude to recommend this game if it's at a price that you deem is "pocket change." It's thrilling. You'll have fun. You'll be glad you didn't spend a significant amount of cash on it.
